Package com.ibm.vie.mazerunner

package com.ibm.vie.mazerunner
This package provides the objects and methods needed to interact with the game. The Move class defines the moves that can be returned from IPlayer#selectMove.
  • Move.NORTH
  • Move.SOUTH
  • Move.EAST
  • Move.WEST
  • Move.BACKTRACK

The player's current position can be obtained from the IBoard that is provided to the IPlayer#selectMove method by calling the getPlayerLocation() method.

The IBoard instance automatically keeps track of the squares that your character has already explored. You can retrieve the moves from the player's current position that will move the player to unexplored squares by calling getUnexploredMoves().

Just because a square is unexplored does not mean it is a good move. Some squares cost more than others to walk into. The most extreme example (Walls) will cost all of your steps if you walk into them. At all levels except level 8, there is a path to the treasure(s) that will only cost you one step per move. A good approach would be to start by only considering moves that will cost one step, as that will work for almost all boards. You can get the cost of a potential move using the following approach.
  1. Get the player's current position
  2. Find the target location of the move by applying the move to the current position. Move#apply(com.ibm.vie.mazerunner.Location).
  3. Get the square on the board for the target location. IBoard#getSquareAt(com.ibm.vie.mazerunner.Location).
  4. Get the cost of moving to the square. ISquare#getStepCost()

You can get the locations of all remaining treasures by using the getTreasures() method. The method returns a list Treasure objects, and you can call the getLocation() method on these objects.

There are several different ways to calculate the distance between two points; a simple one is the manhatten distance .

One possible approach to choosing the next move might be to use a heuristic. In other words, score each NORTH, SOUTH EAST and WEST move and choose the move with the best score.
You might use combinations the following criteria to calculate a score for a move:
  • Distance from the treasure
  • Cost of making the move
  • Number of times the square has already been visited
You might also invent some metrics that are not included here.
A successful algorithm will make moves that explore new squares until it arrives at the treasure. Repeated exploration of the same squares has a cost, and does not yield new information. Top algorithms will avoid repetition.


The BACKTRACK move and the getUnexploredMoves() method enable you to implement a path finding solution.
A simple algorithm might be:
  1. When you arrive at a square where there are (good) unexplored moves, choose one of the moves.
  2. If there are no good unexplored moves, then turn around and return (backtrack).
This algorithm can be used to traverse the maze since it will follow all unexplored (good) moves. It does not find an optimal solution. In addition, there is a significant cost to actually returning a backtrack move from selectMove, since the player will be traversing the same squares several times.

More advanced algorithms build on the simple algorithm, and these can be used to plan a solution path that will avoid repeated visits to the same square. When multiple solutions exist, many advanced algorithms still do not guarantee the optimal solution. Planning a path in advance is not easy, but is a great way to improve your score.
